questions.question: In the hydraulic analogy experiment, flow rate (Q) helps calculate:

explanations.a: Radial velocity is related to slider motion, not flow rate.
explanations.b: Flow rate (Q) is used directly to calculate water flow velocity.
explanations.c: Angular velocity is measured from rotation, not flow rate.
explanations.d: Tangential velocity is related to angular motion, not Q.

questions.question: If relative flow velocity is zero, Coriolis acceleration is:

explanations.a: Coriolis acceleration cannot be maximum when relative velocity is zero.
explanations.b: Coriolis acceleration is proportional to relative velocity, so it becomes zero.
explanations.c: It is not equal to angular velocity.
explanations.d: Coriolis acceleration is well defined and equals zero.

explanations.a: Power consumption is not found from torque difference.
explanations.b: Torque differences do not measure mass of water.
explanations.c: This difference directly represents torque generated by Coriolis force.
explanations.d: Slider velocity is measured separately, not from torque difference.

questions.question: Using a₁ instead of total area in ac = ρ a_total L² / (2gT):

explanations.a: Using a smaller area does not double ac.
explanations.b: Using a₁ (half the total area) halves the calculated Coriolis acceleration.
explanations.d: It does not increase ac by four times.

questions.question: Why record spring balance with No Flow?

explanations.a: Pump checking is not part of this reading.
explanations.b: No-flow condition does not produce maximum torque.
explanations.c: Water weight is not measured here.
explanations.d: No-flow reading removes friction and windage torque from calculations.

questions.question: Matching theory and practical ac concludes:

answers.b: ac depends linearly on V and ω

explanations.a: Coriolis acceleration strongly depends on velocity.
explanations.b: Both theory and experiment show ac ∝ V × ω.
explanations.d: Radial motion is essential because it creates Coriolis acceleration.
